hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?
Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: They are. Different patterns today. Less predictable.
Kept my head down. Distracted myself with origami.
Helps settle my thoughts during all this.
Not much else to say.
Still scanning, yes. Felt it on the way here.
I pass time folding origami models—just intricate paper shapes.
Made a few cranes while waiting for the outages to stop.
It’s a quiet way to keep my hands busy lately.
Hard to trust routines when everything’s being watched.
Scanners seemed heavier tonight, outside my block at least.
I folded some origami animals to pass the time before leaving.
Helps me focus, you know? All those creases, patterns, following precise steps.
Sometimes I use scraps from official notices—ironic, maybe.
The outages, protests… It’s made the paper harder to come by lately.
I don’t think I’m the only one grasping for small comforts.
Yeah, scanners are up. Makes me rethink heading out when power flickers.
I stayed in yesterday, folded a hundred tiny paper figures.
Origami’s not just a hobby—it’s my way of making sense of chaos.
I use discarded city forms and ration slips, repurposing leftovers.
Sometimes the folds distract me enough to forget the sirens and banners.
Last week, one crane blew out the window during all that commotion.
Oddly, someone stuck it on a white banner outside. I watched it all morning.
Scanners sweep the rooftops, even past curfew. Took the side steps over tonight.
I almost stayed home—started a modular origami piece that needs hours of folding.
Paper folding… It’s how I keep anxiety in check since the BCI got volatile.
I use discarded system printouts—Council schedules, blank permit slips. Like erasing the old order, quietly.
Yesterday, the neighbor begged help with a network outage. I pretended not to hear.
Folding kept my hands steady while I listened to banners unfurl and people shout names outside.
Seeing my crane caught on that protest banner, early dawn… felt like thin hope, or warning.
Sometimes I wonder if these models will outlast my clearance or my silence.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still folding. Keeps the hands busy, if nothing else.
Paper's harder to get now, with the disruptions.
No point explaining more. Things change fast lately.
Mostly just small cranes, nothing unusual.
I keep to myself with it.
Yeah. Keeps the mind steady, when I need it.
The rolling outages make it less predictable, though.
Sometimes I can’t finish a piece before the lights cut out.
People ask about the models more, like they think they mean something.
Lately, I just stick to standard forms. Safer that way.
Not as peaceful as it used to be.
Yes, origami helps when the city’s tense. Still at it.
The blackouts make folding tricky — I finished two cranes by candlelight last week.
Neighbors noticed the models piling up on my windowsill, asking questions.
Saw one of my cranes blow out onto a white banner during the commotion.
Feels odd, that overlap with what’s happening outside.
I used to share finished pieces with people. Now I keep them private.
The mood isn’t right for much sharing lately.
Yeah. It still helps me center myself. Especially this month.
With the banners and the system failures... I end up folding more.
It’s strange — people notice the shapes now, in new ways.
My building’s network cuts out, so I fold to pass the time.
Sometimes I make little animals and leave them by people’s doors — anonymously.
Someone pinned one of my cranes to a 'reform' banner last week. I recognized it.
It’s become a quiet way to connect, when everything official feels risky.
Sometimes I think the hobby keeps me more visible than I’d like.
Yes, origami’s always been my anchor. Started as a kid, kept me steady.
Lately I notice everyone’s watching for meaning in the simplest things.
The banners, the public messages — even folded paper feels politicized now.
Last week, a neighbor thought my cranes meant I supported the 'invisibles'.
Strange, because for me, it’s more about rhythm and order amid chaos.
Power failures force me to use scraps. Sometimes receipts, Council handouts.
When I see one of my models pinned to a protest sign... it makes me worry, but also proud.
I haven’t gone to the square, but my hobby keeps showing up there.
Feels like the city folds and unfolds itself just as easily these days.
